This means maintaining a distance of  metres, or  metre with mitigations . We recommend at this time thatpossible prayer religious services take place outdoors.Can funerals still take place in the lockdown areas Yes. Funerals should be limited to no more than  people and subject to COVID- Secure guidelines. People living outside the lockdown areas may travel into the areas to attend a funeral.Can I holiday in the lockdown area, or visit shops, leisure facilities, or cafes in it Yes. However, you must avoid socialising with people indoors when doing so.Can I travel in a car with someone I do not live with You should try not to share a vehicle with those outside your household or social bubble. And others flagged concerns that the lockdown had been brought in just as Eid celebrations began today.The Muslim Council of Britains secretary general, Harun Khan, criticised the way the announcement was made, saying: With the first day of Eid being today, for Muslims in the affected areas, it is like being told they cannot visit family and friends for Christmas on Christmas Eve itself.Whilst the safety of communities is of paramount importance, as has remained the case from the very outset of this crisis, so is effective communication delivered in a timely fashion.Failure to communicate makes it dficult for communities across the country to continue working together to minimise the spread of the virus, whilst eroding trust in the ability of authorities to steer our course as we tackle the Covid- crisis.Baroness Sayeeda Warsi today slammed the lack of clarity over the message on Good Morning Britain, saying she had received calls up to am overnight by confused members of the community.And Health Secretary Matt Hancock this morning was left trying to defend the move, saying the move had been absolutely necessary.Speaking to Sky News, he said the new rules were crystal clear, saying the test and trace data had shown most of the transmission is happening between households.He added: Everyone can see that the problem with this virus is it thrives on the social contact that makes le worth living.The Health Secretary had last night said he was introducing the new measures with a heavy heart - tweeting the announcement at .pm with details published two hours later before the full guidelines were released this morning.When asked about the Islamic celebration of Eid, he said his heart goes out to the community, adding: Unfortunately this change does mean that people wont be able to get together in their houses, in their gardens.But we are allowing mosques and other religious places to stay open because theyve done so much work to allow for Covid-secure celebration and worship.Labour leader Keir Starmer said he would not argue with local action to reduce the transmission of the virus but said: Announcing measures affecting potentially millions of people late at night on Twitter is a new low for the government’s communications during this crisis.He added: For all the bluster, government has failed to deliver a ing track and trace system that would spot local flare ups like these.THE government introduced new guidelines for parts of England last night - title: neil breen ellen degeneres australia the today show
story: He claimed he couldnt look at Ellen, nor speak to her when she entered the room.Heres more of what we know.Neil Breen is an Australian radio host and television reporter.He has worked for several Australian media outlets including  News, The Sundayand The Today Show.Neil Breen claimed the chat show host had a series of bizarre demands when she appeared on his program, the Today show, in .Neil claimed Ellen was initially supposed to co-host the Today show during her  tour of Australia, but this plan was repeatedly changed by her team.The producer called us aside and said, Now Neil, no one is to talk to Ellen. You dont talk to her, you dont approach her, you dont look at her, he said.Neil, who now hosts his own show, claimed Ellens staff were the only ones allowed to interact with her.He alleged that they walked on eggshells around her and laughed so loudly at her jokes during the interview that he had to tell them to keep it down.Ellen has recently faced backlash after several reports have emerged that the host is mean and rude to her staff and guests.Several people that have either worked with or visited Ellens show are coming forward to denounce her sunny image, claiming that behind the scenes, the comedian is a dferent person.Current staff echo those sentiments and are reportedly “distressed and outraged over their treatment.Despite Ellens reputation as a friend to the stars, many of her A-list pals havent been quick to come to her defense.Earlier this month, Ellen employees revealed bombshell accusations they suffered from racism, fear, and intimidation” on set.One current and  former crew members from the daytime series spoke to BuzzfeedNews about the “toxic work environment” but remained anonymous due to fear of retribution.The outlet said some staff claimed to have been fired because they took medical leave or bereavement days to attend family funerals.Others alleged they were instructed by their managers to not speak directly to the -year-old comedianthey saw her at the office.Following staffers allegations of a toxic work environment, The Ellen DeGeneres shows parent company WarnerMedia has opened an investigation.Ellen issued an apology later as a result of the claims.“On day one of our show, I told everyone in our first meeting that ‘The Ellen DeGeneres Show’ would be a place of happiness - no one would ever raise their voice, and everyone would be treated with respect. Obviously, something changed, and I am disappointed to learn that this has not been the case,” DeGeneres wrote.“I could not have the success I’ve had without all of your contributions. My name is on the show and everything we do and I take responsibility for that. Alongside Warner Bros., we immediately began an internal investigation and we are taking steps, together, to correct the issues. As we’ve grown exponentially, I’ve not been able to stay on top of everything and relied on others to do their jobs as they knew I’d want them done. Clearly some didn’t. That will now change and I’m committed to ensuring this does not happen again,” she continued.There are rumors that Ed Glavin, an executive producer, is about to be fired as a result of an internal investigation into complaints of a toxic work environment at the show, according to The Hollywood Reporter.Glavin was part of a trio of senior producers closest to Ellen, which included Andy Lassner and Mary Connelly. Glavin is allegedly set to exit his role in the near future.People have also accused executive producer Kevin Leman for behaving inappropriately at a company party in  and in May .An internal investigation by parent company WarnerMedia is allegedly taking place after employees came forward about experiencing racism, fear, and intimidation” while working on the talk show.Telepictures - which produces the daytime series - and Warner Bros. - which is in charge of distribution - sent an e-mail to staffers last week to say they’re working with a third party firm, according to Variety.Sources told the outlet in addition to the third party company, WarnerMedia’s employee relations group will also interview current and former workers about their experiences on set.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: 12 lifestyle tweaks prevent 40 per cent dementia
story: Experts have identied a dozen modiable risks from childhood to old age that account for  per cent of cases.It includes too much boozing, too little exercise, smoking, obesity and high blood pressure.Loneliness, pollution, head injury, hearing loss, depression, diabetes and poor education also increase the odds.The report was compiled by  researchers from around the world, who want iniduals and governments to take action.Lead author Prof Gill Livingston, from University College London, said: “We can reduce risks by creating active and healthy environments.” Other suggestions include the wider use of hearing aids, stop-smoking support and safer working practices.While experts say changing the way you live could help prevent dementia, heres exactly what you need to do to stop it in its tracks.Experts state that maintaining a systolic blood pressure of  mm Hg or less in midle from around age  years will help cut your risk.Systolic blood pressure is the number that indicates how much pressure your blood is exerting against your artery walls when the heart beats.This is important asthe pressure is too high then it could lead to complications.The study states that people could try hearing aids.They said the use of hearing aids should be encouraged for hearing loss.It also reduces hearing loss by protecting ears from high noise levels.Pollution is everywhere we go so it can be hard to get away from but there are things you can do to monitor it.The experts said reducing your exposure to air pollution and second hand tobacco can help.Apps are available that monitor the pollution levels outside.While none of us want a head injury, experts says you should be carefulyou are in a profession where you could be more prone to this.Most of us like a tipple, whether its a gin and tonic or a pint, but experts say its important to keep your drinking in check.To prevent alcohol misuse they say you should limit yourself to  units a week.Men can have - units a day and women -.The authors of the report said that this is a good idea at any age but can also reduce your risk of dementia.It states you should also help support others who want to stop smoking.While it may seem like a strange point to list, the experts say that an education is key in making sure people dont develop dementia later in le.Making sure children have both a primary and secondary education is imperative, they say.We all know the benefits of exercise.The researchers said that its important to stay active, especially when you hit the middle of your le.Keeping a healthy le style will lower your chance of diabetes. If you are overweight then you are more likely to develop diabetes and there are signs you can look out for.The government has recently launched numerous plans to help Brits kick start their weight loss journey.The experts say that a healthy weight can help prevent your risk to dementia.Getting yourself into a regular routine and a sleep pattern is always a good idea.The researchers said that more work needs to be done when it comes to connecting sleep to dementia but said that this is part of a healthy lestyle.While a lot of focus is pushed on keeping fit, experts say that its important to make sure you are mentally active through your later years.This could mean doing activities such as reading or even puzzles.Fiona Carragher, from the Alzheimer’s Society, said: “The news that  per cent of dementia cases are, in theory, now preventable is certainly welcome.“While we don’t have all the answers yet, we can take action now to tackle the risk factors within our control, including excessive drinking, obesity and high blood pressure.“Meanwhile, we need public health policies to address other factors, such as air pollution and inequalities in childhood education.” Around , people are living with dementia in the UK, with the figure predicted to rise to .million by .The findings are published in The Lancet and presented at the Alzheimer’s Association International Conference.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: leicester lockdown restrictions decision coronavirus
story: But Health Secretary Matt Hancock confirmed separate households in the city are still banned from meeting indoors in line with the new lockdown for millions across Northern England.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesFrom August , restaurants, cafes, pubs and hairdressers in Leicester city can get back to business.But leisure centres, gyms and pools will remain closed, the Department of Health announced.Cinemas and museums will also reopen after the four-week local lockdown - and religious ceremonies can take place under the coronavirus lockdown easing.Leicester residents can also go on holiday with members of their own household.Meanwhile, the borough of Oadby and Wigston just outside of Leicester is moving completely out of local lockdown.It comes after Mr Hancocks explosive announcement last night that the same ban on two households meeting inside will be placed on . million people in northern England from midnight.The shock move follows a surge of infections in European countries as fears grow Britain is just two to three weeks behind Spains alarming spike in cases.In Leicester, restrictions were originally put in place by the Health Secretary on June  after a spike in Covid- infections.Labour MP for Leicester West Liz Kendall tonight blasted the Governments management of the local lockdown as shambolic.Ms Kendall tweeted: This has been an unbelievably dficult period for our city but peoples hard work  sacrices have paid off. However, the Govts handling of this lockdown has been totally shambolic and lessons must be learnt for the future to prevent others going through the same.Mr Hancocks shock measures came as England was hit with  new positive cases - the highest number in  days - adding to fears the country is facing a second wave of the virus.Leicester MP Jonathan Ashworth tweeted: Not yet seen guidance but as I understand it #LeicesterLockdown:Pubs, restaurants  hairdressers will reopen but not gyms, Leisure centres, swimming pools.But no household mixing other than bubbles. People cannot stay overnight at another house or meet in private gardens.From midnight, people from two households in Greater Manchester, Blackburn with Darwen, Burnley, Hyndburn, Pendleton, Rossendale, Bradford, Kirklees and Calderdale were also banned from meeting indoors.Meanwhile, Luton will be brought back into line with the rest of the country with its leisure facilities to reopen, the Department of Health also announced.Leicester Mayor Sir Peter Soulsby was told of the Governments plan for the city by health officials on Thursday evening.The measures were relaxed as clothing retailers were among those allowed to welcome back customers on July .But bars, restaurants and hairdressers remained closed, with the mayor accusing the Government of taking a sledgehammer approach.He previously claimed that data provided to city officials highlighted that only  per cent of Leicester had shown higher transmission rates and added he was bitterly disappointed by the announcement.Speaking tonight, Mr Hancock said he was introducing the clampdown for .million people with a “heavy heart” but was chilled by soaring infection rates in Northern England.And he said the spread was “largely due to households meeting and not abiding by social distancing rules”.Members of dferent households are banned from meeting indoors from midnight.Brits with coronavirus symptoms must now self-isolate for ten days - three more than at present - to try to prevent a second Covid- wave. It comes as government scientists say there is a “low but tangible possibility” sufferers are infectious for seven to nine days. Officials expect only a relatively small number to be affected. The clampdown follows a continued spike in cases in parts of Europe. There are about  confirmed cases a day in the UK. Medical scientist Peter Openshaw, of Imperial College London, said: “Keeping the infection rate low is now a top priority.”  Last nights shock announcement came after Boris Johnson warned between ten and  places in Britain are seeing Covid- cases “bubbling up”Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer branded Downing Streets decision to break the news on Twitter late on Thursday night as a new low for the governments communications during this crisis.Earlier today Conservative MP Neil OBrien said: Sounding positive on #leicesterlockdown - hopefully Oadby and Wigston will soon be free to start getting back to normal.Last week we told how Blackburn overtook Leicester to become Britain’s coronavirus hotspot after cases doubled in just one week.The borough of Blackburn with Darwen in Lancashire had a rate of . Covid- cases per , in the seven days to July .Leicester has a rate of . per , people over the same period, according to the latest data from Public Health England .Speaking earlier, the mayor of Leicester expressed his frustration after the Government repeatedly delayed its decision on whether to lt the citys lockdown restrictions.Earlier Sir Peter said: Im incredibly frustrated on their behalf.Im particularly frustrated on behalf of the businesses in Leicester because obviously theyve now had four weeks of extra lockdown.Theyve been promised extra support from the Secretary of State for Health - hes never delivered on it.Weve had a bit of a whisper that we may be getting a couple of million extra but frankly thats not going to go anywhere across a city like Leicester.After lockdown for an extra four weeks, those businesses are struggling and Im really angry on their behalf.In the House of Lords on Wednesday, Leicestershires Labour police and crime commissioner, Lord Willy Bach, highlighted a decrease in positive Covid- tests, saying: The seven-day infection rate has fallen dramatically at a time when huge amounts of testing are taking place.Its time to release Leicester from its chains.People and businesses who have followed the lockdown to the letter are entitled to their freedom.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: universal credit wait campaign lords
story: And in a huge boost for The Suns Make Universal Credit Work campaign, the Lords Economic Affairs Committee backed all of our main asks of the Government for how to repair the troubled benefits programme.Around .million people were on Universal Credit as of the start of April as thousands lost their jobs as a result of the coronavirus pandemic.An extra .million people claimed for the new benefits system since March - and .million claimed advance payments.In a fresh report out today the peers argue that the five-week wait, which The Sun has been campaigning to get slashed down, is the main cause of insecurity.They said it entrenches debt and increases extreme poverty and must be addressed now.People who have had a £ boost to help during the coronavirus crisis should get to keep the cash going forward, they added.The DWP said no one has to wait five weeks for cash as urgent payments are availablepeople need them.Lord Forsyth of Drumlean, Chair of the Economic Affairs Committee, told The Sun: The Suns campaign has revealed many of these problems with Universal Credit and has been calling for change.Our report reinforces the need for the Government to act on these recommendations - and do so now.There is a great wall of unemployment sadly coming our way and there will be many more people dependent on Universal Credit. It needs fixing.One million people are already receiving it and by the time the system is fully rolled out in , nearly  million will be on it.But there are big problems with the flagship new system - it takes  weeks to get the first payment and it could leave some families worse off by thousands of pounds a year.And while working families can claim back up to  per cent of their childcare costs, they must find the money to pay for childcare upfront - we’ve heard of families waiting up to  months for the money.Working parents across the country told us they’ve been unable to take on more hours - or have even turned down better paid jobs or more hours because of the amount they get their benefits cut.It’s time to Make Universal Credit work. We want the Government to:Together, these changes will help Make Universal Credit Work.Join our Universal Credit Facebook group or email UniversalCredit@the-sun to share your story. And he added: “Most people, including our Committee, broadly agree with the original aims and objectives of Universal Credit. However, in its current form it fails to provide a dependable safety net. It has led to an unprecedented number of people relying on foodbanks and not being able to pay their rent.He said some features of the system were harming women, disabled people and the vulnerable.And he added: “Universal Credit needs more money to catch up after  years of cuts to the social security budget and substantial reform to its design.“The five-week wait for a first payment must be replaced by a non-repayable two-week grant to all claimants.The Lords report also recommends that the punitive taper rate should be reduced - another aim of The Suns campaign - to encourage more people into work.And it says all claimants should have a higher work allowance to allow them to keep more of their hard-earned cash too.The Lords also conclude that including childcare support in Universal Credit was a mistake and paying in arrears is a huge barrier to work - as we have repeatedly highlighted.In some cases it has been a disincentive to work, the report says.The Government should remove childcare support from Universal Credit and be made into a new standalone benefit paid, it added.Jonathan Reynolds MP, Labours Shadow Secretary of State for Work and Pensions, said of the report: “Sadly, this report confirms what many have known for a long time – Universal Credit is simply not working. There is clear consensus that the system is not delivering on its objectives and is instead pushing people further into poverty and debt.Ministers should listen to their Conservative colleagues’ calls for a reformed social security system.The DWP said in response to the report it would consider their recommendations in detail.Minister for Welfare Delivery Will Quince said of the report: “The case for Universal Credit has never been stronger. The system defied its critics in unprecedented and unforeseeable circumstances, processing more than .m new claims at pace since mid-March and paying more than a million advances worth hundreds of millions of pounds to those in urgent need within days.“We remain committed to supporting the most vulnerable in society, which is why we currently spend over £ billion a year on the benefits system. We’ve also increased the Universal Credit standard allowance by up to £, a year, as part of a package of welfare measures worth over £. billion.“We welcome the acknowledgement by the Committee that Universal Credit is here to stay and we will consider their recommendations in detail.”IF youre experiencing trouble applying for your Universal Credit, or the payments just dont cover costs, here are your options:Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: thousands could have wrong test coronavirus
story: In test kits sent out to millions of Brits to seethey have the virus, they were able to take nasal samples from lower down, rather than painful and uncomfortable deep swabs.These can be done at home without the supervision of a medical procedure, and scientists said they would be just as accurate.But a new study from officials at the University of Utah studied the accuracy of the self-collected nasal swap.Scientists found only  of  out of  people who had Covid- were picked up by nasal swabs, compared to the deeper ones.The deeper swabs only picked up a maximum of .However, the study has not yet been published in a medical journal or peer-reviewed. It was conducted across hospitals in Utah.It means there is a risk of people being given  negative results, and not isolating as they should.Up to  per cent of people get the virus without showing any symptoms - and people still can pass it on.Experts said that the swabs have less contact with the tissues and are less likely to pick up the bug.Professor Paul Hunter, an infectious disease expert at the University of East Anglia, said the study findings certainly suggest these DIY tests are not as good and miss a proportion.He claimed around  per cent of coronavirus tests could have been missed.But Professor Hunter told MailOnline the study does not prove the tests are useless and called for larger trials of the swabs currently being used in the UK. He said: This study is fairly small and it needs to be repeated using a larger number of tests, preferably in the UK, before we draw reliable conclusions.No singular test produced  results, proving that no test is able to always detect the coronavirus. But researchers said the numbers were not statistically signicant as the numbers are so small.The researchers wrote: Relying on anterior nasal swabs alone could have missed infection in  to  patients compared with nasopharyngeal swabs or saliva, respectively. Missed Covid- cases have major clinical implications affecting isolation decisions for symptomatic  patients and are a lost opportunity for contact tracing.  The Department of Health and Social Care refuted the findings, saying the evidence shows self-tests are just as effective.A spokesperson said: International peer reviewed evidence, and real-world assessments from the Department’s testing programme, has shown that swab tests taken by non-clinically trained iniduals are just as effective as those taken by clinicians. Instructions on how to perform these types of tests are included wherever iniduals are asked to undertake self-swabbing.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: what no deal brexit mean for uk
story: Negotiations continue, but the EU and UK still disagree over future arrangements for areas such as fisheries, state aid and financial services.A No Deal departure from the European Union means leaving without formal arrangements for the future relationship.Britains trade, customs and immigration rules were tied up with the single market and a host of EU regulatory bodies.Mr Johnson had insisted Britain would leave the EU on October  do or die - and was prepared to leave with no deal.The PM said he would rather be dead in a ditch than ask the EU for another Brexit extension.But a proposed law blocking a No Deal Brexit was backed by MPs on September ,  and was passed in the Lords on September .The Benn Act required the Government to either reach a deal - or gain Parliaments approval for a No Deal Brexit by October .The UK ended up leaving the EU on January  with a transition period until December  .While we did leave with a deal - in which this transition period was agreed - there is still the possibility of ending up in a no deal scenario still.If there is no arrangement for our future relationship by the end of this period then Britain will have left the EU with no deal and will trade on World Trade Organisation rules.In August  John Bercow fought with the government to stop it forcing through its Brexit deal by closing parliament.At the same time several Remainer MPs and anti-Brexit lawyers were trying to stop a No-Deal.Days before the Prime Ministers July deadline - the last opportunity to extend the transition period - ministers said Britain is close to abandoning a trade deal.Boris Johnsons most senior aide Dominic Cummings has been pressuring the UKs negotiators to stick to red lines as tightly as possible in order to get the best possible deal for Britain, according to EU insiders.Deputy negotiator Oliver Lewis, who is a close ally of Mr Cummings, was identied as a key blockage in the talks.It came after the EUs chief negotiator Michel Barnier said he would ease his red lines provided Boris Johnsons government showed some compromise.But British and EU negotiators have agreed  percent of a deal and were gunning for a breakthrough on a post-Brexit security pact.To avoid a No Deal, the UK government must agree its future relationship with the EU - the aims of which were established in the -page political declaration.A free-trade agreement is the priority and talks, which started in March, are set to intensy to achieve this.During this transition period the UK is still a member of the single market and the customs union.Butwe leave without a deal we will not be a member of either and have nothing firmed up to replace it, which means Britain will be forced to trade according to the World Trade Organisation - the global body overseeing international trade.This could lead to greater tarfs on imports and exports - resulting in a price hike.Other aspects are also subject to a deal being reached, includingThe Government has launched a new Check, Change, Go slogan to encourage the public to prepare for the end of the transition period in January .A questionnaire on the gov.uk website allows you to answer a few questions in order to get personalised advice on what you should do to prepare for the looming deadline.Businesses are encouraged to start preparing for a new approach to trade with our partners in the European Union.It added: For iniduals this may include registering your residency rights.

title: cops roadblocks bournemouth beach
story: Officers have been asked to work extended shts and weekend leave has been cancelled with temperatures likely to hit C in southern England.Local councillors have now braced themselves for thousands of visitors and have hatched a plan to prevent the chaotic scenes of last month when a major incident was declared.And in London this morning, more than  beachgoers were seen ueuing at Blackfriars Station to board the first off-peak train down to Brighton. On June , Bournemouth council declared a major incident after services were completely overstretched when huge numbers of visitors crowded onto the beach.Roads were gridlocked, hindering emergency vehicles, and more than  tonnes of rubbish were removed from the coastal hotspot in just one day.Last months combination of weeks of lockdown boredom and the UK heatwave - with temperatures soaring to over C - prompted a surge of visitors to the south coast town.BCP Council issued  parking enforcement fines – the highest on record – and responded to many reports of cars parking and causing an obstruction.And the council’s new plan to prevent the same thing from happening comes as Boris Johnson urged people not to lose focus and risk spreading coronavirus.The Prime Minister said this week: Broadly speaking, the only way to control coronavirus iseverybody collectively obeys the social distancing rules and works together to drive the virus down.What I’m saying to people is: don’t lose focus, don’t lose discipline, continue to observe those guidelines, andyou have symptoms, get a test.Supt Richard Bell, from Dorset Police, urged visitors to respect the community.He said: We are definitely not asking people to stay away. We welcome all visitors, but ask them to respect the environment and the community.Supt Bell said the force is not expecting the same level of numbers because last month the pubs, hotels and campsites were all shut – meaning the beach was one of the few places Brits could go.BCP council has also brought in a new scheme which allows them to tow away carsthey have been left in dangerous spots.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bakery worker sacked 44 years pay cash
story: Megan Metcalfe, , was given her marching orders by Birds Bakery in Radclfe-on-Trent, Notts, after it stopped accepting cash for hygiene reasons.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesShe accepted around £ in cash from customers and then used her debit card to pay for the transactions.Ms Metcalfe said: “I realise what I was doing was against company policy. But they had picked up the items and already gotten to the till ready to buy them.”“There’s no way I could let an elderly man or woman walk away telling them they could not buy it because they didn’t have a card. They had also already handled the stock so that would have to be binned or cleaned.”Ms Metcalfe was suspended on June  and then sacked following a disciplinary hearing, with the firm saying it was “with regret” they had to let her go.She added: “I was just trying to do the right thing. I am really upset by it, of course.“I worked at Birds for  years and  of them as a manager. I was told I was endangering staff members’ lives by doing what I did.“At no point did money transfer hands. It was straight into my purse and then I put the payment through on card and showed them the receipt.“I should not have done it but I don’t like to let people down and a lot of these customers depend on us, coming to us every day.”More than a thousand people angered by the sacking have signed an online petition calling for her to be re-employed or compensated.The petition says: Megan Metcalfe was sacked for being kind to her elderly customers in Birds Bakery, after  years of service.“We the people of Nottingham think that decision is absolutely disgusting, no matter the companys Covid- rules on payment processing, the decision to treat a loyal employee this way for a letimes service is beyond belief.It should be handled more appropriately via a simple disciplinary meeting or just pulled to one side and explained why her actions are not appropriate.“But to be sacked, thats not the actions of a reputable employer and well-known brand like Birds.It comes just days after a -year-old woman was told she couldnt buy bread from Birds bakery because she didnt have a bank card.Former hosiery worker Edna Dalchin has never owned a bank card and prefers to pay with cash.She was stunned and embarrassed when staff told her to put items back because they could not take her money.Lesley Bird, chief operating officer at Birds Bakery, said: “At Birds, we take the safety of our staff and customers very seriously – and have very tight procedures in place during this pandemic.“A lot of our customer base are the elderly – many of them vulnerable – and it is our responsibility to keep them, and our staff, safe.“Like many other food outlets, during this pandemic we have asked customers to only use debit cards because notes and coins are not clean – and this poses a risk to our staff who are handling that money.“In the case of Megan Metcalfe she was taking cash from customers and then making payments with her own card.“This contravenes our current health and safety policy relating to Covid- and is also against company regulations.“It was with regret that we had to ask Megan to leave the business because of those two issues.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailHuge changes to millions of peopleaposs freedoms swept in last night with less than three hoursapos notice due to a surge in coronavirus cases. People in the whole of Greater Manchester may no longer meet anyone from outside their household indoors - including homes, pubs and gardens. The affected area also includes parts of West Yorkshire and Lancashire. However, people are allowed to continue to meet outdoors as long as they stay socially distanced. They can still go to work, travel, and go to the pub - though only with their own household. With the laws now dfering across England and the short notice, many people in Greater Manchester, Lancashire and West Yorkshire are confused about what they can and canapost do. Hereaposs the best explanation we can provide of what laws apply, where. Where the law will apply Greater Manchester:City of Manchester Trafford Stockport Oldham Bury Wigan Bolton Tameside Rochdale SalfordLancashire:Blackburn with Darwen Burnley Hyndburn Pendle RossendaleWest Yorkshire:Bradford Calderdale Kirklees What you can be fined for - and how much New laws will be passed to ban meeting people from other households in private homes or gardens. Police will be able to fine offenders £ for a first offence, doubling on each subsequent offence. Under previous similar laws the maximum fine was £,. Fines halvepaid within  days. There will be some exceptions, such as for household bubbles . Other rules - like not visiting care homes, not socialising with people in pubs, and not sharing cars - look set to be guidance rather than the law. However, there is already a nationwide legal ban on gatherings over  people outdoors and people must legally wear a face covering in shops and on public transport. We donapost yet know when the law will be published or take effect.What you canapost do You canapost meet up with friends or family indoors If you live in the above areas, you may no longer meet anyone from outside your household indoors. aposIndoorsapos includes private homes, businesses like pubs and restaurants, and private gardens . The exception is for people who are part of the same aposbubbleapos - more on this below. When it comes to private homes and gardens, this rule will be enforced by law with fines of £. In the rest of England, there is no longer a law on meeting people from other households indoors. However, guidance says meetings should comprise no than two households, and be socially distanced.   You canapost go to the pub with anyone outside your own household If you live in the above areas, you may still go to pubs, restaurants, bars and other venues that reopened from July . However, you may only go with members of your own household. You must not socialise with people you do not live with in other indoor public venues. You canapost go to a pub beer garden with anyone outside your own household Health Secretary Matt Hancock said the ban on socialising in indoor public venues will include pub beer gardens. This means you cannot go to the pub socially with anyone from outside your household - whether youaposre indoors or outdoors.  You canapost meet friends and family in their garden The ban on meeting other households in indoor spaces includes private gardens - even though theyaposre outdoors. This is because to get there, you often have to pass through the house. You canapost have visitors to your home from outside the new lockdown area You may not have visitors to your home from outside the new lockdown area. This will be illegal. But you can meet them in a pubic area like a parkyou follow social distancing rules.  You canapost visit relatives in care homes Last week the government announced care home visits in England could finally resume.  But in the new lockdown areas, care home visits will not resume. Guidance for them says: You should not visit friends or family in care homes, other than in exceptional circumstances. Care homes should restrict visits to these circumstances. You canapost travel in a car with people outside your household The guidance for the new lockdown area says: You should try not to share a vehicle with those outside your household or social bubble. If you need to, try to share the vehicle with the same people each time, keep to small groups and open windows for ventilation. You should also sit as far apart as possible within the vehicle, wear face coverings and clean the inside thoroughly and regularly. You shouldnapost travel to the lockdown area from Scotland The Scottish government issued new guidance today advising people living in Scotland not to travel to the new lockdown areas at all. The guidance says: Travel between Scotland and Greater Manchester, East Lancashire and parts of West Yorkshire should only be undertakenabsolutely essential. Anyone currently in the affected areas does not need toto Scotland early - but should be extra vigilant in monitoring for symptoms.What you can do You can meet up with friends or family outdoors People in the new lockdown area can continue to meet people outside their household in outdoor spaces - like a park, forest or the beach. This is still in line with guidance for the rest of England. The law only restricts gatherings of more than  people. However, guidance says you should only meet in groups of up to two households, or six people - whichever is larger. Each household should remain socially distant from each other.  You can meet people in your aposbubbleapos indoors Since June , people in England have been able to form a support bubble with one other household. To qualy, one of the two households has to have only one adult in it. For example, a single mum or a granddad living alone. If youaposre in a bubble, you can continue this even in the new lockdown areas like Greater Manchester. You should basically treat your two-household bubble asit is one household. You can stop shielding from tomorrow Most of the .million aposextremely clinically vulnerableapos people in England can stop shielding tomorrow. This means they can be asked toto work, and follow the same social distancing rules as the rest of the populationthey wish. This is unchanged in most of the new lockdown area. People in Greater Manchester, for example, can still stop shielding tomorrow. Exceptions are Luton and Blackburn with Darwen, where shielding should continue to August . In Leicester shielding also continues until at least August  and could run in some parts of the city beyond that.  You can go to work and use public transportneeded People living inside and outside of the new area can continue to travel in and out for work Workplaces must implement Covid- Secure guidance. Public transport will continue running for those who need it, with face coverings worn by all. You can travel in and out of the area You may continue to travel in and out of the new lockdown area, as long as you do not break the rules on meetings indoors. People from outside can take holidays in the new lockdown area,they follow the local rules. People who live inside the new area should continue to follow the ban on meeting other households indoors, eventheyaposre outside the zone at the time.  You can go to cafes, restaurants, the gym and other venues - but only with members of your own household All the venues that reopened on July  remain open, with a few exceptions in local areas where there is an outbreak. But you should only go with members of your own household – evenyou are going outside of the restricted area. You can go to a place of worship You can go to a place of worship, but you must socially distance from people outside of your household. The place of worship should also be following Covid-secure guidelines to keep people apart. Officials recommend at this time that,possible, prayer or religious services take place outdoors. This includes mosques, which are celebrating Eid.

The government has confirmed that new rules, banning indoor meetings between households in Greater Manchester and parts of East Lancashire and West Yorkshire, will also apply to bars and restaurants. That means people in those areas cannot meet members of other households in a pub or restaurant. But people can still go to the pub with members of their own household - as long as they stay as one group and donapost socialise with anyone . Gardens are also understood to be off-limits - but you can meet people from other households in parks and outdoor spaces. Confusion abounded on Thursday after Matt Hancock announced a ban on indoor meetings for large parts of the north of England. New measures - affecting millions of people - were due to come into force at midnight. However no guidance had been published and officials appeared to be in the dark on the details of the plans. Furious MPs demanded answers from the Government about the move. Labour leader Keir Starmer said: No one would argue with putting in place local action to reduce the transmission of coronavirus. But announcing measures affecting potentially millions of people late at night on Twitter is a new low for the government’s communications during this crisis. He said the public needed greater clarity from ministers over such signicant changes.  Shadow Cabinet Minister Jonathan Reynolds, who represents Stalybridge and Hyde in Greater Manchester, said: I have to say a few tweets from a Minister late at night is not the way to announce something as signicant as this. Mr Hancock announced the move at .pm, saying households gathering and not abiding by the social-distancing rules was a reason for the stricter rules and it was in order to keep the country safe. He said: We take this action with a heavy heart but unfortunately itaposs necessary because weaposve seen that households meeting up and a lack of social distancing is one of the causes of this rising rate of coronavirus and weaposll do whatever is necessary to keep the country safe.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA bakery worker tried to get around her companyaposs no-cash rule by taking money from customers and paying at the till with her own card. And she was sacked when bosses found out - bringing to a sudden end a -year career with the same company.Megan Metcalfe told NottinghamshireLive that she was given her marching orders as her actions were deemed to amount to gross misconduct. Popular Birds Bakery has not been accepting cash for hygiene reasons since reopening following the coronavirus lockdown.They say it is to minimise any risk to staff and customers.  Yesterday, we reported how a -year-old customer was shocked and embarrassed when a Birds branch refused to sell her bread because she only had cash.And today Megan told of how many of the customers at the Birds store where she worked, in Radclfe-on-Trent, are elderly and donapost have a debit card. To make sure they didnapost leave empty-handed, the -year-old of Ruddington decided to ask them to put the money straight into her purse. She would then put the payment through on her card before showing them the receipt. The bakery business said it was with regret that they had to dismiss Megan because of her actions. I realise what I was doing was against company policy. But they had picked up the items and already gotten to the till ready to buy them, Megan said. Thereaposs no way I could let an elderly man or woman walk away telling them they could not buy it because they didnapost have a card. They had also already handled the stock so that would have to be binned or cleaned. Megan says she took around £ of payments in cash and put them through on her card and has kept receipts of the transactions.  She said she was suspended from work for a week with full pay on June  and appeared before a disciplinary hearing the week after before being dismissed from the company. I was just trying to do the right thing. I am really upset by it of course, she added. I worked at Birds for  years and  of them as a manager. I was told I was endangering staff membersapos lives by doing what I did. At no point did money transfer hands. It was straight into my purse and then I put the payment through on card and showed them the receipt. I should not have done it but I donapost like to let people down and a lot of these customers depend on us, coming to us every day. Lesley Bird, chief operating officer at Birds Bakery, said: “At Birds, we take the safety of our staff and customers very seriously – and have very tight procedures in place during this pandemic. A lot of our customer base are the elderly – many of them vulnerable – and it is our responsibility to keep them, and our staff, safe.

story: NewsCosta del Sol deserted as Brits stay away amid fears of coronavirus second waveEXCLUSIVE: Bars, beaches and restaurants have been left empty following the governments announcement to impose a -day quarantine for Brits ing from SpainShareCommentsByAdam Aspinall:,  JUL NewsThe Costa del Sol has been deserted as Brits stay away amid fears of a coronavirus second wave " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email The Costas are deserted as Brits stay away after Health Secretary Matt Hancock said a second wave of coronavirus is rolling across Europe.Usually busy hotels have been shutting their doors since the Government ordered quarantine for those ing from Spain. Businesses in popular resorts slammed the Government’s “draconian” move, which came just weeks after Spain was put on the UK’s list of safe countries. At Malaga airport, the gateway to the Costa del Sol for millions of Brits each year, half-empty planes landed throughout the day from airports across the UK. Many of the passengers who did make the trip said they were only doing so as they had a business or holiday home in the area. One tourist from Belfast said their flight was “barely % full” while another said theirs was “virtually empty”. Barely any Brits could be seen entering through arrivals, though there was a steady stream from nations such as France, Germany and Holland. A Spanish tour rep said: “This should be full of British right now . It’s so sad.” At the taxi rank, one of the many waiting drivers said: “Everybody is very angry with the British Government, it was a stupid decision by them, not based on facts.” Up the coast on the Costa Blanca, hotels in Benidorm began to close including the four-star Rio Park Hotel. Usually packed at this time of year, with % of its customers British package holiday tourists, it began to close its doors just six days after reopening. About four in five hotels in the town’s Rincon de Loix area are closed. Mr Hancock denied he was stoking up panic after he warned there was a “real danger” of the UK being hit by a fresh spike in cases. He said: “I think you can see a second wave starting to roll across Europe. We’ve got to do everything we can to prevent it from reaching these shores and to tackle it.” Jet said it will evacuate Brits on holiday in Spain and the Balearic and Canary Islands “up to and including August ”. Holidaymakers were told to cut short their holidays and book alternative flights. A spokeswoman said: “We apologise for any inconvenience caused.” Tonight it was announced that people ing from Luxembourg will have to quarantine for  days after a rise in cases there. It came amid speculation that other European countries including Belgium could be added to the list today. Spain’s tourism sector could take £billion hit this summer as the fresh restrictions take another chunk out of balance sheets already battered after months of lockdown. Bosses are hoping an upcoming review of the quarantine order could lt the restriction within days. Tourism Minister Reyes Maroto said: “They have given us a period of  days for the review.” She insisted resorts popular with Brits are “at low risk” of coronavirus and even “better” than the UK. Spain is still fighting for destinations such as the Canary and Balearic Islands to be excluded from the quarantine rule. Ms Maroto said: “There has been talk of a second wave of the pandemic but we’re not at all at that point. “The new outbreaks are under control and are in very specic places, and Spanish tourist destinations at the moment have very low levels of contagion. “That means people can enjoy their holidays there. The virus needs to be respected but that doesn’t mean we can’t have well-deserved holidays.” Spain announced , new cases on Wednesday, the highest -hour figure since May  when the entire country was still on full lockdown.

The -year-old, from Rochdale, is now dealing with people in Leicester who’ve tested positive for Covid-. A number of changes have been rolled out to the job in recent weeks - including a new measure to track down people who donapost answer calls from the team. Where contact tracers would have previously had four days to try and reach people, that’s been reduced in the outbreak groups.  Atexplains: “If after  hours we can’t make contact with them, we escalate it and a team will go to the household and conduct an interview instead of after  hours. That’s key,” he says. The new methods mean Ataposs vital job now involves so much more than just contact tracing. He went on: “When we call anyone from Leicester, we discuss with them in more detail support we can offer – such as help with food shopping and picking up prescription medication. ‘‘It’s hoped having people to do their essential shopping and pick up prescriptions will increase levels of compliance and make self-isolation easier.” Sarah Hartle , a dental hygienist from Manchester, is another NHS Test and Trace caseworker who has seen her job change to help fight coronavirus.  As pubs, restaurants and shops opened up, she and the team faced new challenges when tracing contacts, so they were given extra training to get the right information from people who’d tested positive for coronavirus. “What’s changed is the questions we’re asking the patients,” she says. “If they were in a shop, were they wearing a mask  Was the shopkeeper  Did they pay by cash or card  Were they maintaining social distancing  If you are doing all those things, the people in that particular shop are not classed as contacts. It’s all based on science. Social distancing does work.” And with the NHS Test and Trace team regularly updated on the latest advice and improvements in the system put in place, they’re able to give people the relevant help they need. She adds: “One recent patient needed a Hindi speaker. The system for that is now so simple and quick, the patient is only on hold for about  seconds and then youaposrere back with the interpreter.”

story: NewsopinionDr Miriam Stoppard: Ethnic minorities being failed by lack of inclusive planningThe pandemic has starkly revealed that BAME people are less likely to use Covid- testing services – we need to look at issues from their point of view to find solutionsShareCommentsByMiriam Stoppard:,  JUL NewsopinionTesting kit instructions can be hard to understand for people whose first language is not English " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe longer the pandemic lasts, the more inequality we uncover.Now we learn both access to testing and its uptake is uneven across all socioeconomic groups, with BAME coming out worst. It’s not just in the UK that ­disparities exist – it’s worldwide. Action is needed to correct this so people from ethnic minorities are included in national and local health planning. Catherine Dodds of Bristol ­University and Ibidun Fakoya from King’s College, London suggest the way forward in an editorial in the BMJ. To keep the R number below one, governments are relying on ­nationwide testing and contact tracing until we have a vaccination programme in place. But while we wait, inequalities mean BAME Covid- infections and deaths keep rising.As Dodds and Fakoya point out we already know uptake of medical testing and screening is uneven across cancer risk assessment, antenatal screening, and HIV testing. The NHS is aiming to expand testing with self-administered swab kits – but this strategy may serve minority groups badly, bearing in mind a  UK study found uptake of HIV self-sampling kits among them was low compared with other groups. Most admitted they would probably not use the kits. Behind this reluctance were privacy issues and kits with complicated instructions that were inappropriately worded for people whose first language wasn’t English. Dodds and Fakoya emphasise until these faults are corrected it’s dficult to see how trust can be built up among our ethnic communities. Isn’t it time we looked at these ­disparities from the BAME point of view, and started framing instructions in a form that’s understandable, acceptable and useful for ethnic minorities instead of imposing a “one-size-fits-all” approach  Given the disproportionate and devastating impact this pandemic has already had among our ethnic minority communities, testing equality needs to be addressed in Covid- screening.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA grieving mum-of-two who had lost her dad was hounded with unwanted gts and messages by a company boss she met on dating website Plenty of Fish. Emma Murby, , had split up with Timothy Green but he bombarded her with flowers, chocolates and sent her a new vacuum cleaner in a bid to win her back while she was in mourning. The teacher, who lives in the village of Eldwick, near Bingley, West Yorkshire, begged the -year-old company managing director to leave her alone - but he left her scores of messages, a Pandora ring and even posed as one of her friends to send her a condolence card. Police eventually the former golf club boss for harassment. At Stockport magistrates court, Green from Wilmslow, Cheshire who runs a company which provides safety inspections admitted harassment. He was banned from contacting Miss Murby for two years under the terms of a restraining order. The court heard the couple had met online in April  on POF and met in person for the first time at the end of that month. Prosecutor Mark Pritchard said: They then had a long-distance relationship where the defendant was living in Wilmslow and the complainant was living in Eldwick. They spent time together at weekends and sometimes met up in the week. At this point the complainant says it was a normal relationship and that she was happy. In August last year she moved in with him for a short period of time and their relationship became strained.  She moved back and after some time the relationship ended. That is when the defendant began his unrelenting course of harassment towards his victim. On March  this year the victim told police she had broken up with the defendant but he continued to contact her. He continued to send flowers and leave voicemails asking her to call him. She replied saying aposI am blocking your calls and voicemails donapost call me again. Stop harassing me.Leave me alone we are not together any more. Do not contact me anywhere.apos But he left her  messages in March,  in April, seven in May. After the victimaposs father died he sent messages to her reporting to be her friend Nick and sent her a condolence card. On the day of her fatheraposs funeral he messaged her saying he had been in a dark place had continued to send messages and cards after from a number of dferent accounts on Plenty of Fish- which all used the same photograph of him.  On May  he sent a vacuum cleaner part to her address which she believes he did to have a reason to contact her. Between  June and  June this year he contacted a friend of the victim numerous times asking about her. On June  he sent her a Pandora ring which she had owned when they were together with tape attached to it. Green later told police he thought Miss Murby had PTSD and that she was blaming him for it. He said he blamed her for him being on anti-depressants. In mitigation his lawyer Steven McHugh said: He is mortied at the position he is in today. He fears going to prison and is taking things seriously. He is not looking for favours and is realistic. The last point of contact was on  June and he wishes to move on with his le. He does not object to the restraining order. He does not wish to reacquaint himself with the complainant. He did not threaten her when he contacted her and had a mistaken belief that contacting her would resurrect the relationship. He pleaded guilty at he earliest opportunity and accepts there was no provocation at all.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMuslims in towns and cities plunged into new local lockdowns overnight face ruined Eid al-Adha plans.Larger celebrations must be cancelled in fresh frustration for families only just able to reunite after months apart during the coronavirus lockdown.Good Morning Britain host Adil Ray explained how devastating the news will be for Muslims in the north: It is, just to explain to the rest of the nation, it is like waking up on Christmas Day and realising that you cannot go to your familyaposs house and have Christmas dinner, or they cannot come and visit you.The government ordered Greater Manchester, east Lancashire, and parts of West Yorkshire into sudden local lockdowns in a shock move last night.The change sparked fury as Health Secretary Matt Hancock announced the policy affecting thousands late last night on Twitter, before releasing further guidance late last night and this morning.The health secretary has claimed the transmission is due to people visiting friends and relatives without following social distancing rules. The lockdowns came into force at midnight - coinciding with an important holy date on British Muslimsapos religious calendar. Has your Eid been affected by the new lockdown measures  If so get in touch: webnews@trinitymirror Eid al-Adha, aposThe Feast of Sacrice,apos begins today and traditionally is a time for families to gather and celebrate together. Familiesapos preparations for meals together will be in tatters in affected northern areas, as gatherings are restricted to households once again. Mosques in the north which had been painstakingly planning socially-distant Eid prayers have however received clarity they can go ahead. The decision sparked widespread fury in the affected counties, as the new restrictions were announced suddenly last night - leaving many Brits with unanswered questions about the new rules. Visiting people at home or even in gardens is now banned in vast swathes of northern England.  Health Secretary Matt Hancock stoked further confusion this morning when he told the BBC people could still visit pubs and restaurants in the lockdown areas - but only with their own household. But as Adil explained on GMB: You have to remember for the the Muslim community, theyaposre not gonna go to pubs itaposs not really their thing, so the idea of having it at home is the core element. Baroness Sayeeda Warsi told GMB the lockdown rules that kick in today remain unclear to many people in affected areas. She said: Itaposs till unclear had phone calls this morning right through to am, into the early hours of the morning saying aposwell what does that mean apos  Because thereaposs still not clarity on whether you can meet outdoors, thankfully there was some clarication that those mosques that had already prepared for Covid Eid prayers with the proper procedures in place would be allowed to go ahead. But i think the lack of clarity and the lateness of the message hasnapost encouraged what effectively throughout the pandemic has been a community-wide response across the UK. Mr Hancock this morning denied that the action taken was being aimed at curtailing Eid celebrations. Asked on BBC’s Today programme whether the measures were announced late on Thursday night to stop Eid celebrations from taking place, he said: “No, my heart goes out to the Muslim communities in these areas because I know how important the Eid celebrations are. “I’m very grateful to the local Muslim leaders, the imams in fact, across the country who’ve been working so hard to find a way to have Covid-secure celebrations. “For instance celebrating Eid in parks where there’s more space available and of course outdoors is safer than indoors.” The new lockdowns broaden the restrictions imposed due to an outbreak in Oldham, in Greater Manchester, earlier this week. Oldham Council said there had been a spike in cases in younger people in their twenties and thirties, with many cases arising in Pakistani and Bangladeshi communities.  Household spread had been a aposreal issueapos, the council said, with multiple iniduals from the same household testing positive. Oldham Mosque Council considered whether it was safe to hold Eid prayers, but decided to go ahead with extra measures in place after consulting all the mosques in the town. Oldham resident Asghar Mahmoods told the Manchester Evening News before the new lockdowns were revealed: Itaposs not great news for the Asian community in general, not being able to interact with families and loved ones. Itaposs one of those things - people need to be a bit more educated. Itaposs definitely impacted on our plans. But you make a bad situation into a good one. We can use technology to speak to our families. Itaposs not all doom and gloom.the weather is good we can sit in gardens. What is Eid al-Adha  The second Eid of the year, Eid al-Adha begins today and comes after Muslims made the Hajj pilgrimage to Mecca in Saudi Arabia. Hajj usually sees millions of Muslims visiting the holy mosque but Mecca heavily restricted the traditional annual pilgrimage this year due to the coronavirus pandemic.

The hotel chain, which is now starting to open for business, has come up with a genius soluition to inspire Brits seeking a change of scenery after months of lockdown. Premier Inn, which is opening its hotels in phases, is taking the phrase aposa change of sceneryapos to a whole new level with a unique ‘view-finder’ to help people choose where to staycation.With thousands of Brits sharing their desperation for a change of scenery during lockdown on Twitter, Premier Inn has developed a solution which will replace their repetitive lockdown views with some of the stunning landscapes available to Premier Inn customers this summer.The ‘Change of Scenery’ device fits over your existing window, using a k digital screen – the latest in home viewing technology – to replace the view with a stream of the best views across the country - handpicked from a selection of Premier Inn’s  locations.  To change the view, users simply press a button on a remote control, just like changing channel on your TV. The device offers a view for every mood, including city landscapes, the classic seaside, breath-taking countryside or historic destinations. It’s the perfect solution for Brits who are looking to upgrade the boring view from their home or ‘window shop’ for their summer break destination. The first trial of the new Change of Scenery Window service took place at a family home in London, where the owner described the dull view as one of the most uninspiring parts of lockdown and a reason for the family’s eagerness to have a change of scenery. The hotel chain is looking at ways to roll the service out for Brits who are unable to travel this summer, ensuring they can still enjoy the beauty of Britain from the comfort of their home.  For those who cannot wait for the full service, a compilation of some of the country’s best views will be made available to stream via the brand’s YouTube channel. It allows Brits to simply turn the screens in their home into windows with views of some of the nation’s most loved locations including London, Durham, Newcastle and more. Plus, as the UK starts to ease out of lockdown, more views from around the UK will be added including Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland so Brits can find inspiration for whatever type of trip they are looking forward to. Premier Inn’s Managing Director Simon Ewins said: “We know many of our guests are bored of the view from their home, so we wanted to create a way to give them a taste of the beautul views available to them this summer, when staying with Premier Inn.  With an enhanced cleaning regime and some great deals available so people can book and stay safely with confidence, we’re really looking forward to welcoming guests for a staycation as summer really starts to get underway.” With online searches for UK staycations increasing by over % in comparison to the average of the past three years , it’s clear that many people are itching to make the most of their summer in Britain. To ensure Brits can make the most of their staycations, Premier Inn has thousands of rooms from £, and with plenty of value on offer, now is the perfect time to book a great value stay in hundreds of locations across the UK.

Nikole Thompson, who has two kids, explained that she is moving into a new build property soon with her family. So to keep her home in tip top shape she created a daily, weekly, monthly and annual schedule. The self-proclaimed avid cleaner works  hours per week, but still manages to tackle chores that most of us would be keen to avoid every morning like emptying the toaster or deep cleaning the coffee machine. She took to the Hinch Army Cleaning Tips group on Facebook to share her y list with fellow mums - but she received a mixed response. Day to day Nikole will make all of the beds, wipe down the bathroom, do a load of washing, before hoovering and heading to the kitchen. But she also set aside a list of tasks that need to be completed monthly, like washing the dog beds and cleaning the oven. In April she steam-cleans the carpets and in December she polishes the Christmas decorations.  Talking of the cleaning plans, one person said: Iaposm far too lazy to be this organised but well done you!! Another asked: Do you have a template at all  I struggle a lot with lack of motivation and canapost get anything done. This would help so much to tick off each day week or month. A third commented: I think this is brilliant! Well done you for being so organised! I’m going to try and take a leaf out of your book! You sound like superwoman to me added a fourth.  However one added: Le is too short. Someone once said to me, live le, no one wants to be remembered for cleaning their house. And another said: Blimey do you do anything but clean  As some people still couldnapost believe how much she cleans every day, she was forced to explain just how long it takes on average to complete each task. Daily tasks include:Make beds -  minutes, my son makes his own bed and i just straighten it upTidy up all rooms -  minutes, putting hair make up stuff away and the odd toy Pick up washing -  minute - the boys in this house have a decent aim. Wipe down bathrooms - a minute per bathroom - so maybe  minutes in total giving  minutes to get between the  Put in a load - again no more than  minutes Hoover downstairs -  minutes Empty dishwasher -  minutes Hoover upstairs -  minutes Wipe down work tops -  minutes Wipe down cabinets -  minutes Load dishwasher -  minutes Clean toilets -  minutes So all in all -  minutes  Plus give it five minutes rising and drying the dog food, maybe another five minutes generally cleaning the dining table, extra sweep of the floor after tea etc, wiping down the hob. On a weekend, its probably more like an hour a day with the extras on the Sat Sunday cleaning. Although most members were supportive of Nikoleaposs rigid cleaning schedule, she did receive some criticism which she later addressed. Responding she wrote: Can I just say that I love my children and husband very much. I work  hours a week and manage no problem to spend quality time with them. This cleaning I already do but I like a good visual, which also helps with delegation.

story: NewsKim Jong-un subjects North Koreans to cruel new law in crackdown on defectorsThe North Korean despot is cracking down on defectors after anti-government leaflets were sent over the border from South Korea - but its putting extra strain on citizens already subject to tight travel restrictionsShareCommentsByRyan Merrield:,  JUL NewsKim Jong-Un is cracking down on defectors " %, rgba, rgba, url"News, views and top stories . You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailNorth Korean leader Kim Jong-un has imposed a cruel new law in a major crackdown on defectors, it has been claimed. Citizens who live in or travel to regions of the Asian country bordering China are being forced to sign a pledge confirming they will never defect, according to reports. The dictator is now requiring anyone in the hermit kingdom traveling to border areas to submit a document with their finger print and a confirmation they will not permanently leave. The extra red tape - which came into place earlier this month - is causing major disruption to business, wedding and funeral travel in a country where the  million residents already need special domestic travel permits. One person who lives in the North Hamgyong province told Radio Free Asiaaposs Korean Service prior to the new regulations, citizens had to verbally declare they had no plans to defect - while showing a certicate of citizenship as well as character references. Stamping another fingerprint to get a travel certicate is not that dficult, but it is unpleasant that so many confirmation documents have been added, and people going to the border areas feel frustrated that they are being treated as potential escapees, they said. The restrictions are part of a government campaign to discredit exiles after anti government propaganda leaflets were floated across the border from South Korea.  According to reports, some citizens are missing important family events because they did not prepare the necessary documents in advance. One source is reported as saying those who live near border areas are always treated as potential escapees. One resident of the Ryanggang province on the Chinese border told RFA they have to pass through checkpoints with ID cards, as well as up to five certicates and the written pledge. Meanwhile, relatives of those who flee the country while traveling to the border region are subject to punishments including internal exile.

story: NewsTwo-legged puppy saved from death in dog meat slaughterhouse finds loving homePoor pup Emma Roo was just eight weeks old when she was mutilated in a slaughterhouse as they prepared to sell her for meat.
